about.title: About Sudan
about.overview_p1: The Republic of Sudan is a country in Northeast Africa. This page will include history, culture, and travel advisories. Content is placeholder and ready to be connected to CMS or backend later.
about.overview_p2: For official information, please contact the Embassy for the latest updates and resources.
about.brief_p1: Sudan is located in the north‑eastern part of Africa and occupies 1,886,000 square kilometers, making it Africa’s 3rd largest country by area. It borders seven countries and the Red Sea, and hosts the world’s longest river, the Nile. Before the secession of South Sudan in 2011, Sudan was the largest country in Africa.
brief_list2: Coastline: 853 km on the Red Sea
Other tributaries: Bahr el Ghazal, Sobat, Atbarah
Borders: Libya, South Sudan, Egypt, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Chad, CAR
about.brief_p2: The metric system is the legal standard in Sudan; traditional measures are sometimes used locally.
about.travel_p1: Airplanes, buses, trains, ships, and multiple land crossings connect Sudan with its neighbors. Land frontier length is approximately 6,780 km across Egypt, Libya, Chad, Central African Republic, South Sudan, Ethiopia, and Eritrea.
travel_routes: Sudan–Egypt: Halayib customs checkpoint; road to Suez via Shalateen and Abu Ramad.
Sudan–Libya: Jebel Oweinat border; tracks to Dongola and Kutum.
Sudan–Chad: El Geneina (SD) – Adré (TD) main crossing.
Sudan–Eritrea: Kassala – Teseney checkpoint; other northern entries.
about.travel_within_p1: All means of transport are available. Overland travel is common due to an expanding road network and legacy rail lines.
about.travel_air_p1: Sudan Airways and Badr Airlines connect major cities; foreign carriers operate routes to Khartoum. Travelers from Romania typically connect via regional hubs.
about.travel_marine_p1: Sea links serve nearby countries on the Red Sea. River transport complements overland routes in some areas.
about.travel_rail_p1: Historic lines (Khartoum–Atbara–Port Sudan; Nyala–Khartoum; Wadi Halfa–Atbara–Khartoum) support passenger and freight. Trips range ~24–30 hours depending on route.
about.travel_motor_p1: Key corridors include Khartoum–Atbara, Khartoum–Damazin, Khartoum–El Obeid, Khartoum–Kadugli, Khartoum–Port Sudan, and Nyala–Kass–Zalingei. Seasonal tracks can be impassable during the rainy season (Jun–Sep).
about.culture_family_p1: Communities are traditionally formed around extended families and lineages, with respected elders guiding social life. Family ties influence opportunities, marriage, and local leadership. Urbanization blends traditional customs with modern life in Khartoum, Omdurman, and other cities.
about.culture_family_p2: Social gatherings often observe gender segregation in traditional settings. In cities, families work and study alongside diverse ethnic groups. Upper‑income households in major cities are closely connected to public service, business, and the professions.
tourism_places: Sudan National Museum (Khartoum) — artifacts spanning from the Stone Age to medieval eras.
Ethnography Museum (Khartoum) — cultures, customs, and tribes of Sudan.
Al‑Khalifa House Museum (Omdurman) — Mahdist period history near Al‑Mahdi's Tomb.
Sheikan Museum (El Obeid) — Mahdist relics and regional history.
Sultan Ali Dinar Palace Museum (Al‑Fashir) — Darfur heritage.
about.tourism_cultural_p1: The Whirling Dervishes of Sudan are renowned for rhythmic devotional dances. Cultural centers and libraries in Khartoum host exhibitions, language programs, and forums (e.g., Abdel Karim Merghani Cultural Center, Goethe‑Institut, French Institute, British Council).
about.visiting_intl_p1: With a dual African‑Arab heritage and a strategic location, Sudan plays an active role in regional and international organizations, including the UN, AU, Arab League, OIC, COMESA, IGAD, and others. Sudan advocates non‑interference, mutual benefit, and a rules‑based international order that promotes justice and development.
about.visiting_bilateral_p1: Sudan maintains diplomatic ties worldwide, including strong relations with countries across Africa, the Middle East, Europe, and Asia. For Romanian travelers in Bucharest, the Embassy of the Republic of Sudan provides consular services, visas, and travel guidance pertinent to Sudan.
about.visiting_challenges_p1: Sudan continues to address internal challenges while pursuing stability and constructive engagement abroad through its embassies and consulates.
